BASKETBALL WOULD BE MORE POPULAR
The decision as to whether Johns Hopkins will be represented
by a swimming team or a basketball team this winter will be
decided by the Athletic Council within a week. We do not know
anything about the finances relative to conducting either team,
but we believe that the student body is in favor of basketball.
In the first place, a swimming team, judging from the material
available from last year, could at the very best make only a fair
showing, and would probably make a very sorry one. A basketball team is at least a gamble.
It is almost certain that the attendance at basketball games
would be greater than that at the swimming meets for the past
few years. Basketball is often a thrilling game to watch, whereas
most swimming meets afford little excitement. If the question
of finances can be satisfactorily solved, the Athletic Council would
undoubtedly cater to popular opinion in establishing basketball as
a minor sport.

How unfortunate that the University wits—perhaps the two
wittiest wits of all—should hide their lights under bushels until
occasion arises for derogatory and retroactive criticism, and then
appear in full force, but in rather an unfavorable light. We refer,
of course, to the recent exchange of caustic comment between the
editors of the two campus journals.
It was not until the appearance of the recent issue of the Jay
that editorials were included in the pages of our humorous magazine; sad to relate, when this first dedicatory blurb was printed,
all other humor, instantly put to shame, crawled back into its hole,
and threatens to stay there until editorials are denied space.
Consider the subtle satire exemplified in the Jay editorial. The
author "merely wishes to point out that derogatory criticisms are
very often retroactive." This, after a vivid description, pantingly
real, of the make-up of the NEWS-LETTER. To have refrained,
under the circumstances, from a damnation of derogatory criticism, would obviously have been a much safer procedure; but
we must not forget that the editor is above all a humorist; therefore he criticizes derogatorily, and then criticizes derogatory criticism. Amazement—breathless amazement—such as that with
which we first greeted Lindy's triumph, is the first emotion provoked by this daring coup d'etat; then admiration begins its subtle
work, and we acknowledge the writer as a master of whimsical
and astounding contradiction, a delightful humorist, and a worthy
editor.
The man has a fondness for "b's." His b's sting. And how!
And how? Beginning bitingly with bravado more boisterous than
his brother's, be beats his blustering way, becoming better and
better as he brings up "new brooms" and "dusty bulletin boards,"
battering down banalities with blows of his bludgeons and becoming bewitchingly brilliant with his beautiful b-stung "bits of biweekly blarney." There! Ah, how heavily failure falls on an
unimaginative but thoroughly worshipful imitator! There is a
ring in his style that none save Macaulay could have inspired or
:mitated, a splendid sonority, a weighty antithesis, a dignified
obscurity
On the one hand, then, we have this newly-discovered humorist'
who edits the Black and Blue Jay in his "spare hours"—and it is
not until his calm humor is ruffled in a well-directed but unnecessary attack, that his powers are noticed.
But the other hand! We've had editorials for years and years;
occas'onally we have had interesting editorials; years ago, Henry
Turnbull wrote exciting editorials, but never has a humorist
steered the NEWS-LETTER while another handled the Blue Jay.
Another editor, confronted with such a blasting broad-side of
bombastic bull, would have done a very sane and extremely common-place thing; Henry Jarrett, for instance, would have ignored
the remark and continued his pompous and sensible "spare-hour
art" without retort he would have been secretly proud of his
ability to overlook such unmerited criticism.
But did our Morton do that? Not he! Not for him, the
obvious and snooty silence; not for him, the devastating reply of
utter ignorance. No! He ups and says, "S' Too Bad," with a
twinkle in his eye, and then he sneers cynically through three

NOTE ON FRENCH
Any college course picked at random will offer many, targets
to would-be critics. Either the students, or the professor, or the
subject matter of the course, or the manner in which the course
is conducted, usually has something wrong with it.
Like most courses, French 2 has a defect or two. How, when
most undergraduates have difficulty appreciating English poetry,
can they be expected to get either an intellectual or an oesthetic
pleasure from reading French poetry? This has worried us for
a long time. Part of French 2 consists of an appreciation of
Musset, Lamartine, de Vigny and a few others, but we doubt if
more than one or two students each year are able to do any more
than to translate these men's work more or less literally, much less
effect a literary translation. How much more would they appreciate the Contes drolatiques.,

TWO ON THE SAME NIGHT
Some four or five years ago some one conceived the idea of.a
University "calendar" as a means of avoiding the scheduling of
more than one function on one night. Of course, like all minor
constructive measures, it was adopted only to be forgotten immediately. Every year the Student Council exhorts the various
activities to register its dates in the diary: every year there are
clashes.
Tonight is the first. The Musical Club announced a tentative
schedule several weeks ago, setting tonight as the date of its opening concert. Through some one's carelessness, the Cotillon Club
has also scheduled an affair for this evening. Tonight's conflict
is a relatively unimportant one, but even these could be avoided
if the managers would be more careful.

BASKETBALL WOULD BE MORE POPULAR
The decision as to whether Johns Hopkins will be represented
by a swimming team or a basketball team this winter will be
decided by the Athletic Council within a week. We do not know
anything about the finances relative to conducting either team,
but we believe that the student body is in favor of basketball.
In the first place, a swimming team, judging from the material
available from last year, could at the very best make only a fair
showing, and would probably make a very sorry one. A basketball team is at least a gamble.
It is almost certain that the attendance at basketball games
would be greater than that at the swimming meets for the past
few years. Basketball is often a thrilling game to watch, whereas
most swimming meets afford little excitement. If the question
of finances can be satisfactorily solved, the Athletic Council would
undoubtedly cater to popular opinion in establishing basketball as
a minor sport.

Any college course picked at random will offer many, targets
to would-be critics. Either the students, or the professor, or the
subject matter of the course, or the manner in which the course

Like most courses, French 2 has a defect or two. How, when

can they be expected to get either an intellectual or an oesthetic
pleasure from reading French poetry? This has worried us for

inen on the field didn't know what

undergraduates.
